issue.title: Use pre-built cross-compiled aarch64 gcc for x86-64 linux machine
issue.body:
[//]: # (SPDX-License-Identifier: CC-BY-4.0)
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
Made x86-64 linux machine to use the pre-built corss-compile aarch64 gcc
Added x86-64 linux GitHub runner, it will only cross compile the project, emulation on qemu will be done in other PR

- **add arm gnu gcc nix spec for x86_64**
- **use the pre-built cross-compiled gcc for x86_64 machines in ci**

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->

<!-- Any PR adding a new feature is expected to contain a test; the test should be part of CI testing, preferably within the ".github/workflows" directory tree. Please add an explanation to the PR if/when (why) this cannot be done. -->

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review. -->

comment.body:
If we're using `zig` for cross compiling, other than updating the dependencies, adding something like this in the `Makefile` is all we need I think. (Then we can get rid of the `arm-gcc-gnu.nix` file that I added in this PR)

```
CC := zig cc
TARGET ?=

ifdef TARGET
        ZFLAGS += -target $(TARGET)
endif

...:
  $(CC) $(ZFLAGS) ...
```

Then in CI we will need to specify the target when cross compilation is needed (i.e. `make TARGET=aarch64-linux-gnu`)

issue.title: Introduce common coeff_signed_to_unsigned function in poly.c
issue.body:
This PR introduces a common "coeff_signed_to_unsigned()" function in poly.c, its contracts and verification thereof using CBMC. This function reduces repetition of the same idiom in poly.c and simplifies the calling code in poly_compress() and other functions.

Additionally, this PR adds contract-based proof of scalar_compress_q_16 and scalar_compress_q_32

comment.body: @rod-chapman Linting fails (check the formatting of `poly.[ch]`), as well as CBMC.

issue.title: Explore the use of CBMC
issue.body:
Relates to: #37 

[CBMC](https://github.com/diffblue/cbmc) can be used to verify the absence of certain classes of undefined behaviour in C programs. This issue asks for an exploration of the potential use of CBMC for hardening of mlkem-c-aarch64.

Acceptance criteria:
* PR opened illustrating the use of CBMC for one or more selected C functions in mlkem-c-aarch64.
* Decision made on whether to use CBMC for wider parts of mlkem-c-aarch64.

comment.body:
@mkannwischer @cothan I am positive about the use of CBMC to prove absence of [some classes of] UD for the C code. I don't think it will be feasible to show functional correctness for anything beyond very simple functions.

I think we should strive to roll this out more broadly.

issue.title: Update nix channel to 24.05
issue.body:

[//]: # (TODO Customize PR template)

[//]: # (See https://docs.github.com/en/communities/using-templates-to-encourage-useful-issues-and-pull-requests/configuring-issue-templates-for-your-repository )

<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
- **update to nix 24.05**
- **format c files**

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->

<!-- Any PR adding a new feature is expected to contain a test; the test should be part of CI testing, preferably within the ".github/workflows" directory tree. Please add an explanation to the PR if/when (why) this cannot be done. -->

<!-- Please answer the following questions to help manage version and changes across projects. -->

* [ ] Does this PR change the input/output behaviour of a cryptographic algorithm (i.e., does it change known answer test values)?  (If so, a version bump will be required from *x.y.z* to *x.(y+1).0*.)

<!-- Once your pull request is ready for review and passing continuous integration tests, please convert from a draft PR to a normal PR, and request a review from one of the OQS core team members. -->

comment.body:
In nixos channel `24.05` astyle version is `3.4.15`, I downgraded astyle to `3.4.13` to avoid some weird formatting.

In version >= `3.4.15`, for example, `a * b` will be formatted as `a *b`

issue.title: Setup native and emulated test CI
issue.body:
https://github.com/pq-code-package/mlkem-c-aarch64/pull/22 adds native test.

In addition to that I'd like to add support for cross-compilation and testing in qemu. That should also allow running the tests in the Github CI. 
We do have something similar in https://github.com/slothy-optimizer/pqax that could give some inspriation. 
There is CI there too: https://github.com/slothy-optimizer/pqax/pull/4

comment.body:
- [ ] Native tests on AArch64 Linux runners. Done in https://github.com/pq-code-package/mlkem-c-aarch64/pull/49
- [ ] Native tests on Mac. Done in https://github.com/pq-code-package/mlkem-c-aarch64/pull/44 
- [ ] Cross-compilation on x86 Linux runners: Build. Done in #45 
- [ ] Cross-compilation on x86 Linux runners: Test.

issue.title: Add CBMC as dependency to nix
issue.body:
Right now we are assuming that the user has installed:
 - CBMC: https://www.cprover.org/cbmc/
 - https://github.com/model-checking/cbmc-viewer
 - Litani: https://github.com/awslabs/aws-build-accumulator

This PR moves that into the nix dependencies, so the developer can just type `nix develop` to install it. 
It also allows us to make sure alle developers are running the same versions of these tools (and we can install updates when needed).

comment.body:
> @potsrevennil points out that this is going to be easy by using pkgs.cbmc.overrideAttrs with a new version or commit hash from the repo. You can ping us once you actually need a newer version and we can change it. We won't need to write our own build script.

Sounds great. Can you still set this up with 5.95.1 (obtained from the repo) for now?
